p: Adult female Cx. p. pipiens (3–9 days old) and Ae. aegypti (4–6 days old) mosquitoes were injected with SHUV into the thorax to investigate the role of mosquito barriers on dissemination of SHUV. Mosquitoes were anesthetized with 100% CO 2 and positioned on the CO 2-pad. Female mosquitoes were intrathoracically injected with 69 nl of SHUV (P3 stock with a titer of 3.0 x 10 6 TCID 50/ml) using a Drummond Nanoject II Auto-Nanoliter injector (Drummond Scientific, Broomall, Unites States). Injected Cx. p. pipiens were maintained at 25°C and injected Ae. aegypti were maintained at 28°C. Mosquitoes were incubated for 10 days at the respective temperatures, and had access to 6% glucose solution ad libitum. Injections were done during a single replicate experiment for Cx. p. pipiens (N = 50) and Ae. aegypti (N = 50).
